answers.answer: Don't know what it means that it went down, but that is still too low.  Normal ranges by the AACE are 0.3-3.0.  Sounds like you need to find a good endocrinologist who specializes in thyroid or a thyroid specialist for him.Good luck and let us know the outcome.

Depending on age, children's levels are a little higher than adults.I don't know if diabetes effects thyroid levels.   However, levels do and can fluctuate for many various reasons.  As long as TSH fluctuates or changes within Labs reference range, I would assume it it would be of no concern.AACE 2006 (amended version) page 9 and the US Government 2004, has set the guidelines for diagnose for Overt Hypothyroidism and Levothyroxine therapy  reasonable with a TSH Higher Than 10.  TSH levels and treatment is also based on different factors and conditions, such as nodule/goiter.The  AACE TSH 0.3-3.0 that everyone keeps referring to, is a target range once diagnosed and on meds.  Not a diagnose level. AACE revised/amended version 2006 - page 9.Good luck with your boy! Keep him tested on a regular bases so if anything does show up it can be caught before problems occur.

question: my son has diabetes he recently had a tsh done and he was 7.5 then he came back a week later and had it done again and it went down to 5.3 does that mean anything that the #'s went down or is there still a problem?
title: elevated tsh
